content: Survival function estimation, commonly used in medical analytics, raises privacy concerns due to information leakage. A differentially private estimator is proposed to address this issue, providing strong privacy guarantees while maintaining good utility. The method is extended to provide confidence intervals and test statistics, as well as estimation of competing risk cumulative incidence function. Empirical evidence from clinical datasets supports the effectiveness of the proposed method. The survival function is crucial for modeling time to events in various domains, such as healthcare. Information leakage in healthcare is a serious issue, with personal healthcare data being highly sensitive. The Kaplan-Meier method is widely used for estimating the survival function in clinical research, highlighting its importance in reporting cohort survival statistics. The Kaplan-Meier method is commonly used in clinical studies and by statistical agencies worldwide to report survival statistics. Currently, there is no model that can provide formal privacy guarantees for estimating survival functions using this method. Existing approaches are limited in their applicability, and generative models like GANs may not generalize well to small, constrained datasets typically encountered in this context. We propose a differentially private method for estimating survival functions based on the Kaplan-Meier method. Our method guarantees private estimation of survival functions, confidence intervals, and test statistics without extra privacy cost. It extends to competing risk cumulative incidence functions and has been validated on real clinical datasets. The method is available as an R package for easy adoption.
